meanings.definition: To sail faster or better than another ship.
meanings.sent1: During the race, our ship was outsailing the competition effortlessly.
meanings.sent2: The skilled captain managed to outsail all the other boats in the regatta.
meanings.sent3: The pirate captain boasted about outsailing the navy with his clever tactics.
meanings.sent4: The small fishing boat outsailed the storm, reaching the safety of the harbor.
meanings.sent5: With determination and skill, the sailor outsailed the rough waves to victory.

meanings.sent1: Despite the strong winds, the experienced sailor was able to outsail his companions.
meanings.sent2: She trained hard to outsail her fear of the open sea and finally set sail.
meanings.sent3: The young sailor challenged his mentor to a race, hoping to outsail him and prove his skills.
meanings.sent4: In the competition, only one captain could outsail the rest and claim the trophy.
meanings.sent5: The determined crew worked together to outsail the storm and reach the distant shore.

meanings.definition: The act of sailing faster or better than another ship.
meanings.sent1: The outsailing of the sleek yacht left the spectators in awe.
meanings.sent2: In the history of naval battles, tales of outsailing have always been celebrated.
meanings.sent3: The annual regatta showcased the thrilling competition of outsailing among the participants.
meanings.sent4: The record-breaking outsailing of the clipper ship became legendary in maritime lore.
meanings.sent5: With grace and speed, the outsailing of the majestic vessel captured the attention of all.
